awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative: Computational Cognitive Modeling of User Security and Incentive Behaviors
awd_abstract_narration:
User behavior is a critical element in the success or failure of computer security protections.  The  field of Human Security Informatics (HSI) combines security informatics and human-computer interaction design to learn how the design of a human-computer interface can affect the security of a computer system. This research project is contributing to the scientific foundations of HSI by modeling how multitasking users behave when making security-critical decisions.  In particular, the researchers are modeling user behavior when the users are engaged in typical PC-based mobile messaging with security concerns such as phishing or spam.  The project is evaluating how well the models capture the impact of incentives and interventions on user security behaviors.

This project extends the cognitive modeling (CogM) architecture to characterize and improve user security decision-making and behaviors. Focusing on cognitive constructs in the ACT-R and Soar architectures, it models the multi-tasking application and security activities with varying cognitive traits and security constraints, through representations of productions and information chunks, as well as their utility and activation calculations. An analytic user model not only describes a problem in making a security decision, but also can explain why and how it happens for incentive and intervention selection. Moreover, CogM models and empirical user testing comparatively study common and advanced users in typical messaging applications, regarding security mistakes and efficiency in task completion. This project is focused on establishing the principles for analytically modeling user cyber behaviors and bridging the gap from understanding security behaviors to effectively improving security performance.

por.por_cntn:
Information technologies increasingly impact every person in every daily task. At the core of information processing, human cognition is critical to decisions that impact security. Researchers have studied user behavior in cybersecurity to test hypotheses on various factors, helped by empirical experiments and self-reporting by users or experts. In general, these studies provide "black box" or "product theory" models of security behavior to describe correlation between inputs and outputs. In this project, we adopted an innovative two-prong approach: (1) We simulated users detecting phishing emails based on a cognitive chunk activation model that varies a set of parameters. (2) We analyzed and compared simulation outputs and data collected from real empirical studies to gain insight into challenges facing a human user. Computational cognitive models focus on underlying psychological processes producing human behaviors during operation selection and problem solving. Such an analytical model can shed additional light into plausible causes and strategies, based on emerging cognitive conditions, to provide guidance toward an effective remedy. 

This research provides inspirations to diversifying and expanding research efforts in human security dynamics that ranges from physiological to social behaviors. It shows a great potential by combining methods of user attitude survey, empirical study, and analytical modeling and simulation. This project also aims to facilitate human factors research in cybersecurity on different cognitive and problem solving levels by sharing collected data, code, and models through a public repository (behavior.isi.jhu.edu). The data has already been utilized in machine learning of security behavior by a collaboration team at the University of South Florida. Our students have also used the project data for other security research topics including behavioral biometrics. 

We first conducted several pilot user studies to understand the capacity and constraints of computer users processing emails that expose them to the danger of phishing. These studies were in a controlled lab setting to examine various factors including incentive and potential interventions. At last, we deployed a large empirical study of phishing detection on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Over 200 participants recruited from US sorted emails into legitimate and phishing categories using a real webmail system in an unattended manner. A subset of these participants was exposed to a secondary problem solving task and/or an incentivization scheme that rewards high sorting accuracy. Data analyses show a few findings, some of which are consistent with existing literature: (1) Multitasking significantly worsens sorting accuracy, but incentive alone makes no difference in either multitasking or no-multitasking cases. (2) Multitasking and incentive show opposite effects on email processing times: multitasking reduces users? processing time, while the incentive increases it. However, spending more time on individual emails does not always guarantee better sorting accuracy. (3) Clustering analysis identifies a division of three distinct subpopulations of capable, conservative, and naive users. (4) The roles of cybersecurity training experience, advanced education, and age are noticeable and distinguish different types of users. These findings bear significance to developing effective remedies to counter phishing attempts.

We developed a computational model that utilizes cognitive chunk activation calculation to simulate the decision-making process of a user classifying legitimate and phishing emails. Suspicious-seeming cues in each email are processed by examining similar, past classifications represented by information chunks in long-term memory. An email is considered as a phishing attempt if such information cues contained in it raise enough suspicion. We manipulated five parameters to examine their effects on accuracy, email processing time, and decision confidence, corresponding to the same measures extracted from the empirical study data. Results and comparison analyses have evaluated the effectiveness of this computation modeling approach: (1) The simulation results echo many observations from the empirical study. Examining the model constructs of information chunk processing and associated parameters provides particular explanation of certain patterns and issues in users? email sorting behaviors. (2) However, several limitations of the current model show that it cannot well capture capable users and their sophisticated phishing detection strategies. Future work needs to adapt the modeling tactics of how information cues are used and adopt more dynamic mechanisms in managing the suspicion level of an email. 

Augmenting cybersecurity applications requires a thorough understanding of the boundary and limitation of human cognition and decision-making, especially in the age of IoT and AI. Shown as a promising approach to complement empirical user studies, computational modeling of users? security behavior bears significance to tackling emerging hard problems. Our study helps to identify future research directions for such a comprehensive approach.
